qas.question: What determines the cost of fixing a bug?

answers.text: the earlier a defect is found

qas.question: Ho many more times would the cost be if the problem is found after the software's release?
What could possibly lessen the cost of fixing buggy software?

plausible_answers.text: the earlier a defect is found, the cheaper it is to fix it.

qas.question: What is the unpopular belief about the cost of fixing a bug?
The cost of fixing a defect does not depend on what?
How much less would it cost to fix a problem found after the software's release?

plausible_answers.text: modern continuous deployment practices and cloud-based services

qas.question: What modern items may increase the cost of re-deployment over time?

context: It is commonly believed that <a0_0><b3_0>the earlier a defect is found<a0_0/>, the cheaper it is to fix it.<b3_0/> The following table shows the cost of fixing the defect depending on <b4_0>the stage it was found.<b4_0/> For example, if a problem in the requirements is found only post-release, then it would cost <a1_0><b5_0>10–100 times<b5_0/> more<a1_0/> to fix than if it had already been found by the requirements review. With the advent of <b6_0>modern continuous deployment practices and <a2_0>cloud-based services<b6_0/><a2_0/>, the cost of re-deployment and maintenance may lessen over time.
